# Website Strategy Hub

**PURPOSE**: This hub is the central planning space for our website redesign. It consolidates strategic, technical, and messaging elements to ensure a coherent, audience-centered rebuild.

> 📘 This hub contains everything related to the DCLT website redesign, including evaluations, technical builds, content strategy, and migration planning.

## **Why a Website Still Matters Deeply (and Possibly More Than Ever)**

### 1. **Credibility + Trust Anchor**

- For new donors, partners, volunteers, or media, your website is the first impression and primary *validation* point.
- If it looks outdated or lacks clarity, trust and perceived professionalism suffer-especially in a crowded nonprofit space.

### 2. **Owned Channel**

- It’s the one digital asset you *own*. Social platforms and email providers can throttle reach or change algorithms-but your website is under your control.
- Essential for long-term resilience and mission clarity.

### 3. **Conversion Engine**

- Donation forms, email signups, event registrations, volunteering interest-all critical actions typically happen (or should happen) on your site.
- Without a clear user journey and CTAs, you're losing out on engaged users.

### 4. **Central Hub for Integrated Comms**

- All campaigns (email, print, social, paid ads, PR) should lead back to it.
- A strong content strategy on your site can power everything else-think landing pages, resource libraries, campaign archives.

### 5. **SEO and Discoverability**

- For many, Google is the front door. Your website’s content determines how visible and credible you are in organic search, especially for cause-specific terms, events, and local engagement.

---

## **When a Website Fails (and Why It Gets Undervalued)**

### 1. **It’s Static, Outdated, or Doesn’t Reflect the Brand**

- Nonprofits often neglect regular updates or fail to align the website with current storytelling, impact, or visual identity.

### 2. **No Analytics = No Insight**

- If you’re not using tools like GA4 or Hotjar, you can’t measure engagement or improve UX. That makes the site feel like a black hole, which leads people to undervalue it.

### 3. **Poor Mobile UX**

- Many nonprofits still haven’t optimized for mobile-critical, as up to 60% of traffic is now mobile-first, especially from email or social.

---

### 📈 How Forward-Thinking Nonprofits Are Using Their Websites Today

- **Persona-Based Navigation:** Different landing zones or resource trails for donors, landowners, members, press, etc.
- **Impact Dashboards:** Living, visual storytelling of progress-not just a blog archive.
- **Content Hubs:** Evergreen and campaign-based storytelling, feeding social/email.
- **Digital Stewardship:** Welcome series, donation receipts, and renewal journeys supported by dynamic content tied to donor history.

---

Category: Strategy
End Date: July 29, 2025
Notes: Complete development of logo, alternates,  and usage system.
Parent Task: Visual Identity System (Visual%20Identity%20System%202322a8cd5755801b8d5ae0446918e8ad.md)
Priority: Medium
Start Date: July 23, 2025
Status: Not started
Task Role: Subtask

### **🎯 Purpose:**

Complete and approve the full logo system for DCLT’s rebrand, ensuring flexibility across print, digital, merchandise, signage, and partner usage. Final marks should reflect both strategic direction and visual testing feedback from stakeholders and audiences.

---

### **✅ Definition of Done**

- [ ]  Final primary logo approved (horizontal and stacked versions)
- [ ]  Secondary marks and icon variants created (square, avatar, merch)
- [ ]  Logo works at small and large scale (print, digital, signage)
- [ ]  All versions tested on light/dark and photo backgrounds
- [ ]  Grayscale, black & white, and reversed options finalized
- [ ]  Clear space and sizing rules established
- [ ]  Exported in SVG, PNG, PDF, EPS (web and print kits)
- [ ]  Usage guidelines drafted and linked to Brand Guidelines page
- [ ]  Internal team signoff and stakeholder validation complete

---

- 🎨 Visual Identity System (Parent Task)
- 📁 Brand Audit Summary
- 🧠 Key Insights → Future Brand Strategy Steps

---

### **⏱️ Time Estimate:**

8-16 hours (including design work, testing, revisions, and approvals)

# -- Modular Content Blocks

## Purpose

Define reusable content components that will appear across multiple pages on the new DCLT website. These blocks are the building units of page templates, campaigns, and story-driven layouts.

---

## 🔄 Block Inventory

| Block Name | Description | Appears On | Source Content Type | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Hero (Image + Headline + CTA) | Full-width hero section with overlay text | Homepage, Campaign Page | Campaign, Story, CTA | Often dynamic or configurable |
| Featured Story Block | Pulls a single story w/ image, excerpt, CTA | Homepage, Sidebar, Preserve pages | Story | Could be filtered by category or tag |
| CTA Panel (Join, Give, Volunteer) | Modular call-to-action block w/ icon and button | Global (sidebar, footer, inline) | Supporter CTA | May be context-aware |
| Preserve Card Grid | Tiled visual layout with short preserve data | Explore page, Homepage | Preserve | Needs filtering logic |
| Program / Events Block | Upcoming events in list or card format | Homepage, Explore pages | Event / Program | Optional RSVP button |
| Testimonial Quote Block | Highlighted quote, name, role | Campaign, Homepage, Donate | Story | Could tie to donor or volunteer persona |
| Statistic / Impact Panel | Number + description + icon (e.g., 8,000 acres protected) | Homepage, About, Campaign | Annual Report, Project | Reusable in multiple places |
| Map Embed Block | Interactive map or location graphic | Explore, Preserve detail | Conservation Map Tool | Could filter dynamically |
| Related Content Block | Cross-links to related content | Preserve, Story, Project | All | Logic: tag or related field |
| Accordion / FAQ Block | Expandable Q&A section | Visitor Info, About, Strategic Plan                               | All | Use for quick clarity sections |

---

## 🧭 Page Template Mapping (Example: Homepage)

1. Hero Block
2. Featured Story
3. Preserve Grid (Top 3-6)
4. CTA Panel (Give/Join)
5. Events Block (Upcoming)
6. Impact Stats
7. Testimonial
8. Footer with newsletter signup

---

## 🛠️ Implementation Notes

- Blocks should be **modular in WordPress**, either via:
    - ACF Flexible Content
    - ACF Block-based editor
    - Or separate CPTs fetched dynamically
- Match each block with a **GraphQL fragment** in Astro for clean querying and rendering

[  --- Master Modular Block Field Definitions](%E2%80%94%E2%80%94%20Modular%20Content%20Blocks%201f12a8cd57558061a6c9d9314be3cd49/%E2%80%94%E2%80%94%E2%80%94%20Master%20Modular%20Block%20Field%20Definitions%201f12a8cd575580708d65d0deb83f009f.csv)

# Set Engagement KPIs

Category: Strategy
Notes: Define benchmarks for campaign impact
Parent Task: Communications Plan (Communications%20Plan%202322a8cd57558057958af2cf755b6b2a.md)
Priority: Medium
Start Date: July 25, 2025
Status: Not started
Task Role: Subtask

### **🎯 Purpose**

Define clear, measurable engagement benchmarks that will guide DCLT’s communications, digital strategy, and donor outreach. These KPIs will serve as the baseline for performance tracking across channels.

---

### **📌 Goals**

- Identify priority metrics by audience segment (e.g., new members, major donors, volunteers)
- Establish benchmarks for email, web, social, and campaign interactions
- Align engagement goals with strategic milestones (e.g., campaign launch, member renewal)

---

### **📊 Scope**

- Document 5-10 core engagement KPIs
- Tag KPIs by funnel stage (Awareness, Consideration, Action, Retention)
- Determine how KPIs will be tracked (e.g., Google Analytics, Salesforce, Constant Contact)
- Establish targets (quarterly or annual) based on historical performance + strategic goals

### **✅ ✅ Definition of Done:**

- [ ]  Dashboard draft created in Salesforce
- [ ]  Fields mapped to metrics in KPI list
- [ ]  Stakeholder review completed
- [ ]  Dashboard shared in team meeting

---

Establish a clear, memorable brand personality that reflects DCLT’s values, resonates emotionally with both legacy and emerging audiences, and provides a consistent voice across all touchpoints.

---

### **✅ Definition of Done**

- [ ]  Core personality attributes selected (e.g., trustworthy, grounded, welcoming, bold)
- [ ]  Tone and voice guidelines drafted (how we speak, write, and present ourselves)

- [ ]  Do’s and don’ts list created for writing and speaking style
- [ ]  Examples of tone across key formats (web, email, signage, social)
- [ ]  Draft reviewed by 1–2 internal stakeholders for alignment
- [ ]  Final doc linked to Brand Guidelines and Messaging System

# Brand Storytelling Pillars

Category: Messaging
End Date: July 22, 2025
Notes: Align with conservation values and public language
Parent Task: Brand Strategy Framework (Brand%20Strategy%20Framework%202322a8cd575580eb9575dfc525909b52.md)
Priority: High
Start Date: July 16, 2025
Status: Not started
Task Role: Subtask

Draft the core storytelling messages that tie land conservation, legacy, and ecological health into a coherent identity for DCLT’s outreach.

To establish a consistent, compelling narrative framework rooted in mission, values, and audience motivations—used across campaigns, website, donor appeals, and outreach.

---

### **🔍 Scope**

- Aligns with: Strategic Plan                                ([[Campaigns]]), Visual Identity, Audience Segmentation, and the 2025 Comms Plan
- Serves as a messaging spine for all storytelling—written, spoken, and visual
- Designed to work across multiple platforms: web, print, email, social, video

---

### **📁 Components**

- 3–5 core narrative “pillars” that encapsulate key ideas (e.g., “Land Legacy,” “Community Stewardship,” “Nature’s Resilience”)
- Each includes:
    - Title + taglines or shorthand
    - Emotional drivers (hope, urgency, belonging, awe, etc.)
    - Associated calls to action
    - Suggested audiences
    - Example phrases and tone

---

### **🧩 Integration**

These pillars will inform:

- Website content blocks
- Email series
- Video scripts
- Campaign one-pagers
- Story-based donor segmentation
- Staff/board talking points

---

### **✅ Definition of Done**

- [ ]  3–5 narrative pillars are defined with emotional drivers and example language
- [ ]  Each pillar is mapped to at least one key audience/persona
- [ ]  Visual and story applications have been tested across two formats (e.g., email, landing page, donor appeal)
- [ ]  Pillars reviewed and validated by internal stakeholders (e.g., Dev + Outreach + Executive)
- [ ]  Pillars documented in the Messaging System and linked from the Comms Strategy hub

---

### **📎 Related Pages**

- ✍️ Storytelling Strategy & Campaign Framework
- 🧠 Audience Segmentation & Messaging
- 🖼️ Brand Strategy Framework
- 📢 Campaign Messaging Pillars (detailed use examples)
- 📋 2025–2026 Communications Plan

# Rebuild Homepage Wireframe

Category: Website
End Date: July 31, 2025
Notes: Apply modular layout with storytelling CTA blocks
Parent Task: Website Overhaul (Website%20Overhaul%202322a8cd575580b3a7dff15efa901e94.md)
Priority: High
Start Date: July 20, 2025
Status: Not started
Task Role: Subtask

Reimagine the homepage layout to reflect DCLT’s updated brand strategy, strategic priorities, and modern user expectations. This wireframe should serve as the foundation for future design, development, and storytelling.

### **📌 Goals**

- Establish a strong visual hierarchy
- Elevate mission, impact, and calls to action
- Make segmentation, storytelling, and navigation intuitive
- Prioritize mobile responsiveness and accessibility

---

### **🛠️ Scope**

- Replace legacy homepage wireframe
- Incorporate modular components (e.g., hero, card grids, CTA bands)
- Align with messaging pillars and brand narrative
- Integrate top-tier campaign messaging if available

### **✅ ✅ Definition of Done:**

- [ ]  Updated wireframe reflects revised brand strategy and modular content blocks
- [ ]  Key homepage components placed with purpose: hero, featured story, preserve grid, CTA panel, event block, impact stats, testimonial
- [ ]  Wireframe includes notes on user flow, content hierarchy, and CTA placements
- [ ]  Team has reviewed and signed off in Figma or Notion
- [ ]  Wireframe is documented and linked from the Website Strategy Hub

---

# 🧰 Messaging Toolkit

A living library of modular content pieces: headlines, CTAs, intros, segment-specific messages, and story formulas.

**Purpose**: Speed up content creation while keeping voice, tone, and structure aligned across all channels.

---

## 🧠 Strategy Notes

- Categorize messages by **purpose**: join, renew, give, volunteer, protect land
- Align with **archetypes** and **personas**
- Reuse across formats: website blocks, email PS lines, social captions, campaign blurbs
- Include **“voice ladder”** for emotional tone (from soft → bold)

---

## 📋 CTA Library

| 🏷️ Action | 🧠 CTA Example | 🎯 Best For | 🧭 Archetype |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Join | *Become a Wild Door Sustainer today.* | Email, Web | Quiet Neighbor |
| Give | *Your gift protects land for every season to come.* | Campaign, Donation Page | Legacy Steward |
| Volunteer | *Put your boots where your heart is.* | IG Post, Volunteer Drive | Active Participant |

---

## ✨ Headline & Hook Bank

| ✍️ Type | 💬 Sample | 🎯 Use |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Email Subject | *The Forest is Listening* | Monthly Digest |
| Social Caption | *Goldenrod: Door County’s Fall Fireworks* | Carousel Post |
| Web Block Title | *You Make Wild Possible* | Homepage CTA |

---

## 🗂️ Additional Tools (Add Sections As Needed)

- Voice & Tone Ladders
- Word Bank / Vocabulary Guide
- CTA formulas by format (button, inline, PS)
- A/B Test archive

# 📢 Campaign Drafts

Workspace for planning, drafting, and iterating campaign-based storytelling. These sequences may span emails, social, web, and even print.

**Purpose**: Align stories, tone, and calls-to-action with key initiatives like fundraising drives, volunteer pushes, and public announcements.

---

## 🧠 Strategy Notes

- Structure campaigns around clear goals: donations, signups, awareness
- Use **sequenced content** with emotional arc or momentum
- Incorporate **identity-based appeals** (archetypes) and modular blocks
- Start early with brainstorming, then assign format and timeline

---

## 📋 Campaign Tracker

[Untitled](%F0%9F%93%A2%20Campaign%20Drafts%202622a8cd575580208c56dc2d21ab386f/Untitled%202622a8cd575580d0907ee85e61a5885f.csv)

---

## 🧱 Suggested Sections for Each Campaign

- 🎯 Objective + Target Audience
- 🔁 Story Arc or Content Sequence
- ✍️ Drafts for Email / Web / Social
- 🧰 CTAs + Tracking Links
- 📸 Asset List
- 📅 Timeline

# 🎨 Visual Storytelling

A visual companion to your story engine — supporting illustrations, photos, diagrams, and visual metaphors that align with the brand system.

**Purpose**: Strengthen emotional and informational clarity through visuals that enhance storytelling and deepen place connection.

---

## 🧠 Strategy Notes

- Use **photo + illustration pairings** to reinforce content type
- Align with brand tone: woodcut-inspired, natural textures, grounded realism
- Build re-usable assets for key modules (e.g. Preserve Explorer, Giving Tree)
- Consider **motion graphics** for campaign rollouts or story series

---

## 📋 Visual Asset Tracker

| 🎨 Asset | 🧩 Type | 🔗 Campaign / Story | 📅 Status | 📸 Source / Artist | 📁 File Location |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Monarch Map | Infographic | Fall–Winter Email | Draft | Olivia | /Campaigns/Fall25/Assets |
| Heron Illustration | Brand Icon | Legacy Circle | Final | Illustrator | /BrandSystem/Icons |
| Field Crew Candid | Photo | Field Notes | Approved | Jack | /Photos/2025_FieldNotes |

---

## 📷 Visual Needs Wishlist

| 📌 Project | 🖼️ Visual Needed | 📅 Target Use | 📸 Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Giving Tree | Animated zoom from whole tree to leaf | Nov | Simulate exploration |
| Preserve Explorer | Icon for “Scenic Overlook” | Oct | Woodcut-inspired |

---

## 🖌️ Style Alignment

- ✅ Woodcut textures
- ✅ Natural light photography
- ✅ Accurate Door County terrain
- ⚠️ Avoid overly abstract or modernist visuals

# 📝 Story Intake Form

Use this template to gather compelling stories from members, donors, volunteers, and partners. Designed for easy copying or embedding into a survey, Airtable form, or internal Notion submission page.

---

## 📋 Story Intake Questions

1. **What’s your name and connection to Door County Land Trust?***(e.g., member, land donor, volunteer, trail user, etc.)*
2. **Tell us a moment or experience that stands out.***(What made it memorable? Where were you?)*
3. **What does land conservation mean to you, personally?***(You can speak from the heart, or tell us how it’s affected your life.)*
4. **If you could tell others *why* this work matters, what would you say?**
5. **Do you have any photos, videos, or drawings to share?***(Optional — attach files or describe what you’d like to submit)*
6. **Would you be open to having your story featured in a newsletter, email, or social post?**
    - Yes / No / Let’s talk more
7. **Any other thoughts or suggestions you’d like to share?**

---

## 🧠 Internal Tags (for staff use)

| Archetype | Segment | Location | Format Potential | Visual Asset Needed? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| e.g. Legacy Steward | Member / Donor | Clay Banks | Email, IG Reel | Yes – portrait, field |

---

## 🔗 Link To:

- 📓 Field Notes
- 📢 Campaign Drafts (e.g. Giving Tuesday, Fall–Winter Drive)
- 📷 Visual Storytelling (if media is submitted)

# 🐾 Seasonal Nature Stories

A rotating series of seasonal, educational, and conservation-themed content ideas. Use these for emails, social posts, web updates, or educational signage cues.

**Purpose**: Connect audiences to natural phenomena, preserve updates, and land trust impacts through timely, relevant insights.

**Good For**:

- Email digests (monthly/seasonal)
- Carousel posts or short reels
- Kiosk/visitor center callouts
- Website sidebar or homepage modules

---

## 🧠 Strategy Notes

- Tie stories to local seasonal cues (e.g., migration, blooms, weather shifts).
- Use plain language but reference expert insight when helpful.
- Include staff or partner quotes when possible.
- Visuals: always aim for strong photo or illustration pairing.
- Consider overlap with stewardship campaigns or land projects.

---

## 📋 Idea Table

| ✅ Status | 📅 Target Date | 🧠 Topic | 📣 Title/Hook | 📍 Format | 🔗 Related Campaign | 📸 Assets Needed | ✍️ Author |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Idea | Late Sept | Monarch Migration | *The Last Flight of the Monarchs* | Email, Social | Fall Fundraising | Photo, Map | Comms Team |
| Scheduled | Aug | Wildflowers | *Goldenrods: Door County’s Fall Fireworks* | Web, IG Carousel | Education | Trail photo | Olivia |

---

## ✅ Content Pipeline Tags

- `Idea` – brainstormed but not started
- `Drafting` – content or visuals in progress
- `Scheduled` – approved and queued
- `Posted` – published (add date)

# 📓 Field Notes

A storytelling-forward series that brings readers into the field—through the eyes of staff, volunteers, or donors.

**Purpose**: Showcase our people, process, and passion for place. Less formal than news—more about presence and personality.

**Good For**:

- Social posts (photo + short caption)
- Mid-month emails or PS sections
- Print newsletters
- Behind-the-scenes reels

---

## 🧠 Strategy Notes

- Capture voice: use quotes, casual tone, or direct speech.
- Pair with strong candid photos or short field videos.
- Reinforce stewardship, community, and transparency.
- Tap seasonal routines (e.g., prescribed burns, cleanup days).
- Consider archetype appeal (e.g. “Volunteer Victor,” “Legacy Ella”)

---

## 📋 Idea Table

| ✅ Status | 📅 Target Date | 🌲 Story Angle | 📣 Title/Hook | 📍 Format | 🧭 Location | 👥 Voice | 📸 Assets Needed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Idea | Oct | Volunteer Spotlight | *Why I Come Back Every Fall* | Email + Reel | Lautenbach Woods | Volunteer | Portrait, field shots |
| Drafting | Aug | Wildlife Encounter | *Caught on Cam: Coyotes at the Creek* | IG Reel | Legacy Preserve | Steward | Trail cam footage |

---

## ✅ Content Pipeline Tags

- `Idea` – spark or interview identified
- `Drafting` – story outline or media gathering in progress
- `Approved` – ready to schedule
- `Live` – already published

# 🗺️ Brand + Website Timeline & Milestones

🔗 See related  [[Brand + Website Progress Dashboard|Brand + Website Progress Dashboard]]  ▪ *status at-a-glance*

![milestone chart.png](%F0%9F%97%BA%EF%B8%8F%20Brand%20+%20Website%20Timeline%20&%20Milestones%202372a8cd5755805198deecfb977e6e72/milestone_chart.png)

## *Purpose:*

> This page provides a **date-anchored roadmap**
> 

> It’s designed for tracking pace, surfacing bottlenecks, and keeping aligned on what’s due when.
> 

> Use this page for:
> 
- Milestone planning
- Timeline visualization
- Scheduling deliverables and launches

> 🔗 See also:
> 
> 
> [Progress Dashboard](https://www.notion.so/paste%20link)
> 

# **✅ Project Roadmap Summary**

## **1. Brand Identity Overhaul**

**Goal:** Redefine DCLT’s visual and verbal identity to reflect mission, values, and evolving audience needs.

### **📅 Timeline (July 2025 – February 2026)**

| **Phase** | **Dates** | **Milestones** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Phase 1: Discovery & Audit** | Jul–Aug 2025 | ✅ Brand Audit Complete🔜 Define Brand Personality |
| **Phase 2: Design Development** | Aug–Oct 2025 | 🔜 Finalize Logo & System🔜 Draft Guidelines🔜 Create Templates & Icon Set |
| **Phase 3: Validation & Guidelines** | Oct–Dec 2025 | 🔜 Staff & Stakeholder Signoff🔜 Publish Guidelines🔜 Archive Legacy Assets |
| **Phase 4: Launch & Implementation                              ([[Brand + Website Progress Dashboard]])** | Jan–Feb 2026 | 🔜 Rollout across platforms🔜 Update internal docs and signage |

### **🔑 Key Milestones**

- ✅ Conducted cross-generational focus groups
- ✅ Completed visual audit & SWOT
- 🔜 Final logo approval
- 🔜 Stakeholder validation
- 🔜 Publish brand guidelines

### **📌 Immediate Next Steps**

- Define Brand Personality (tone, voice, emotional resonance)
- Begin logo finalization and testing once Focus Groups are finished
- Draft early brand system components (color, typography, iconography)

## **🎨 Mission-Aligned Design Approach**

As we move from discovery to execution, our design process will be rooted in **authentic community insights** and **organizational values**.

We’ll use focus group findings to surface the emotional and visual themes that matter most to our audiences — and cross-reference those with DCLT’s own mission, values, and beliefs.

### **🧭 How We’ll Guide Creative Decisions:**

- **Synthesize feedback** from all generational focus groups (emotional tone, visual preferences, language resonance)
- **Map values overlap** between audience feedback and DCLT’s mission:
    - Protection of land and water
    - Community connection and stewardship
    - Legacy, authenticity, and access
- **Define 3–5 brand attributes** to guide design (e.g., *Rooted, Inviting, Enduring, Clear, Natural*)

### **🎯 Design System Principles**

We’ll ask of every visual and verbal decision:

- Does this reflect *who we are* and *who we serve*?
- Is it emotionally resonant *and* clearly legible?
- Does it feel like **Door County**, not just any land trust?
- Can this scale across platforms and generations?

> The result will be a system that’s
> 
> 
> *values-aligned, story-driven,*
> 

## 🧭 Brand Governance & Decision Framework

To keep the rebrand process inclusive yet focused, we’ve defined clear roles, guardrails, and decision points.

### 🔐 Decision-Making Core

A small decision-making group will review and approve major milestones:

- **Communications Manager (Lead):** Owns brand strategy, synthesis, and direction
- **Development Director**: Ensures brand alignment with organizational vision, values, and long-term positioning
- **Executive Director:** Ensures alignment with organizational vision and donors
- **Non-profit strategist volunteer:** Provides branding and engagement perspective from the nonprofit sector; reviews strategic framing and materials
- **Communications Coordinator (Designer):** Executes visual assets and design system components; collaborates on templates, iconography, and digital rollout

This group signs off on:

- Brand personality and tone
- Logo and visual system
- Messaging pillars
- Rollout strategy

## **👥  Roles & Division of Labor**

| **Role** | **Responsibilities** |
| --- | --- |
| **Comms Manager** | Leads brand development, owns Notion system, creates messaging framework, synthesizes focus group data, and sets design direction |
| **Comms Coordinator** | Leads visual system execution, co-develops messaging, manages creative assets/templates |
| **Development Director** | Reviews language and design through donor lens; ensures legacy and philanthropic audiences are represented in tone, voice, and priorities |
| **Strategist Volunteer** | Advises on structure, inclusivity, and nonprofit best practices; reviews at milestone checkpoints |

## 🧑‍🤝‍🧑 Stakeholder Engagement

We are building for *alignment, not consensus.* Community voices shape the work, but don't vote on visual details.

Engagement tools include:

- Focus groups (legacy + newer audiences)
- Staff pulse-checks
- Select donor and volunteer input
- Internal preview + feedback window

## 📌 Division of Roles

| Role | Responsibilities |
| --- | --- |
| **Comms Manager** | Leads strategy, coordinates decision-making, defines visual tone and brand framework |
| **Comms Coordinator** | Executes tasks: documentation, Notion updates, asset prep, presentation support, web/social rollout |
| **Designer** | Develops logo, templates, and brand system in alignment with research |
| **ED/Board** | Approves strategic direction, provides donor/stakeholder lens, avoids micromanaging design |

## 🛠️ Tools & Templates In Progress

- Brand Strategy Doc (values, tone, narrative)
- Stakeholder FAQ
- Brand Rollout Plan (audience-specific)
- Feedback protocols and version control

## **🤝 Creative Collaboration Notes**

> The Communications Manager and Communications Coordinator work as creative co-leads:
> 
- **Strategy + Systems** (Manager)
- **Design + Execution**  + **Messaging** (Coordinator)

> Regular milestone reviews ensure alignment, and all visual decisions are made collaboratively with space for both vision and feedback.
> 

## **🔀 Brand Decision Path: Internal Review vs. External Validation**

As we near the final phase of brand system development (logo, type, color, voice), we face a fork in the road. There are two valid paths forward, depending on the boldness of our creative direction and how much validation we want before rollout.

## **✅ Recommended Brand Validation Plan**

*(Finalizing DCLT’s Visual Identity System)*

This phase bridges internal leadership decision-making with a brief round of supporter sense-checking to confirm alignment and surface any late-stage objections.

---

## **🧩 Core Internal Review**

**Primary Decision-Making Group**

**Participants:**

- **Communications Manager** – strategic lead & facilitator
- **Communications Coordinator** – co-designer & messaging partner
- **Development Director** – audience alignment & legacy insight
- **Executive Director** – mission + fundraising alignment
- **Strategic Volunteer** – brand advisor & nonprofit lens

**Purpose:**

Finalize key components of the brand system:

- Logo
- Typography
- Color palette
- Messaging pillars

**Outcome:**

Aligned near-final brand system ready for validation check-ins.

---

## **💬 Light-Touch External Validation**

**Optional but Recommended (Confidence Boosting Step)**

**Who to include:**

- 2–3 focus group participants
- 1–2 younger/emerging supporters
- (Optional) 1 board member with strong radar for public tone

**How to test:**

- 15–20 min 1:1 conversations *or* short guided survey
- Focus questions:
    - Does this feel like Door County Land Trust?
    - Does it reflect our mission and values?
    - Is it emotionally resonant and trustworthy?
    - Is the design clear and legible?

**Important framing:**

> “This is a near-final system. We’re not seeking design edits — just a quick check for clarity, tone, and emotional fit.”
> 

---

## **📆 Suggested 4-Week Timeline**

| **Step** | **Owner** | **Timing** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Internal brand review (Core 5) | Comms Manager | **Week 1** |
| Revise system based on feedback | Comms Manager + Comm Coord | **Week 2** |
| Run 3–5 supporter check-ins | Comms Manager | **Week 2–3** |
| Finalize brand system | Comms Manager + Core Group | **Week 3** |
| Begin brand guideline creation + rollout planning | Team | **Week 4** |

## **🟡 Key Notes**

- Avoid over-democratization — this is **not** open-ended testing.
- Preserve clear ownership and editorial control.
- Use this step to *build confidence*, *strengthen alignment*, and *preempt last-minute friction* before rollout.

---

---

## **2. Website Overhaul**

**Goal:** Rebuild DCLT.org for modular storytelling, flexible CTAs, and better alignment with supporter journeys.

### **📅 Timeline (July 2025 – June 2026)**

| **Phase** | **Dates** | **Milestones** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Phase 1: Strategy & Structure** | Jul–Sep 2025 | 🔜 Modular Content Block System🔜 Supporter Funnel Strategy🔜 Rebuild Homepage Wireframe |
| **Phase 2: Design & Prototyping** | Sep–Nov 2025 | 🔜 Visual Identity Applied🔜 Page Templates Drafted🔜 CTA Placement Strategy |
| **Phase 3: Development & Integration** | Dec–Mar 2026 | 🔜 CMS/WordPress Setup🔜 Data Sync with Salesforce🔜 Event & Map Integration |
| **Phase 4: Launch & Optimization** | Apr–May 2026 | 🔜 QA & Accessibility Audit🔜 Full Site Launch🔜 Post-launch Testing & Refinement |

### **🔑 Key Milestones**

- ✅ Defined core MVPs for Preserve Explorer
- 🔜 Finalize Modular Block Table
- 🔜 Wireframe homepage + key sections
- 🔜 Sync milestones to dev schedule

### **📌 Immediate Next Steps**

- Complete Modular Content Block structure
- Rebuild Homepage Wireframe
- Define Supporter Funnel and CTA paths

# — Foundations: Visual Strategy & Research

**Designing a Distinctive, Meaningful, and Modular Logo for DCLT**

---

## **1. 🧠 Best Practices in Conservation & Nonprofit Logo Design**

### **✅**

### **Clarity and Simplicity**

- Logos must be instantly recognizable at all sizes (from favicon to billboard).
- Avoid overly detailed linework in the main logo—use simplified icons or glyphs for small-scale applications.

### **Versatility**

- A great conservation logo works in:
    - **Color and black & white**
    - **Digital and print**
    - **Merchandise and signage**
- Build-in modularity: create a system where a full logo, icon, and sub-brand glyph can coexist.

### **✅**

### **Emotional Resonance**

- Strong nonprofit logos evoke trust, care, and place.
- Incorporating symbolic elements tied to **region, community, or mission** deepens the visual connection.

### **✅**

### **Scalability Through Story**

- Use nature-based symbols to connect with a broad audience (e.g., leaf, bird, water, sun).
- Bonus: A stylized map or topographical gesture can ground the design in Door County’s unique geography.

| **Organization** | **Style** | **Why It Works** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Patagonia** | Flat, iconic, silhouette | Color-coded story of wild places. Recognizable across cultures. |
| **National Park Service** | Shield with illustrative elements | Communicates stewardship and tradition. |
| **Nature Conservancy** | Typographic with globe leaf | Clean, modular, eco-centric, scalable. |
| **Save the Redwoods League** | Simple redwood silhouette | Regionally grounded and powerful in its specificity. |
| **Rainforest Alliance** | Friendly frog glyph | Strong mascot for digital and print applications. |
| **Cornell Lab of Ornithology** | Stylized bird glyph + serif wordmark | Elegant and modern, with clear field-specific focus. |

## **3. 🎨 Stylistic Direction for DCLT**

We’ve expressed interest in a style that includes:

- **Minimalism with organic or hand-drawn feel**
- **Freeform layouts** (not boxed in)
- **Extractable glyphs** for sub-brand use
- **Woodcut/vintage-inspired aesthetics**
- **Color symbolism aligned with values**

### **Suggested Visual Archetype:**

A **modular badge** that can flex between:

- **Primary logo**: Bluff + wave + sky stripes + species silhouette
- **Glyph/icon**: A single symbolic element like a samara, feather, or wave curve
- **Seasonal variants**: Subtle color shifts or iconography that evolves through the year

---

## **4. 🌈 Color Psychology and Brand Symbolism**

Here’s how color can reinforce our values:

| **Color** | **Symbolism** | **Tie to DCLT** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Deep Green** | Stewardship, land, growth | Conserved lands, native forests |
| **Lake Blue** | Clarity, trust, water quality | Great Lakes, water protection |
| **Warm Gold** | Community, light, generosity | Legacy Circle, giving, vitality |
| **Clay/Brick Red** | Earth, rootedness | Door County’s geology, historical preservation |
| **Charcoal** | Stability, professionalism | Brand authority |

## **5. 🔧 Design Recommendations**

### **🪶 Symbol Ideas (Primary & Glyphs)**

- **Feather** (lightness, species, migration, glyph-worthy)
- **Samara seed** (natural regeneration, iconic)
- **Wave arc** (water, motion, renewal)
- **Bluff line** (anchor, place-based identity)
- **Silhouetted bird or mammal** (osprey, fox, crane)

### **🧩 Modular System**

1. **Primary Mark**: Bluff + water + nature element, with type.
2. **Glyph/Icon**: Pulled from part of the mark (e.g., wave or seed).
3. **Horizontal & stacked layouts**: Responsive flexibility.
4. **Seasonal/Program Submarks**: Samara in bloom (spring), flying bird (fall), ice edge (winter).

### **✍️ Typography**

- Choose a **highly legible serif or humanist sans**—should feel timeless, not techy.
- Optional: explore a **hand-drawn or woodcut-style type treatment** for texture.

---

## **6. 📈 Bonus Inspiration**

- **Check out the following logos**:
    - *Maine Coast Heritage Trust*
    - *Point Reyes National Seashore*
    - *Save the Boundary Waters*
    - *Redwood Parks Conservancy*
    - *Chisos Mountains Lodge*

Each uses strong symbolism, regional specificity, and clean modular systems.

---

## Colors

Here’s a full color palette tailored to **Door County Land Trust (DCLT)** — drawing from nature, mission alignment, and recent logo explorations. Each color is chosen to work across print and digital, while evoking emotional and environmental cues relevant to DCLT’s conservation identity.

---

### **Primary Colors**

These are our workhorses — used in logos, headers, signage, and major visual branding.

| **Color Name** | **HEX** | **Use Case** | **Symbolism** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Forest Green | #2F5D50 | Primary logo color, headers | Growth, stability, evergreen |
| Lake Blue | #4A8BA1 | Backgrounds, buttons | Clean water, trust, openness |
| Bluff Clay | #D78E59 | Accent in logos, borders, highlights | Earth, shoreline, heritage |
| Golden Prairie | #F0C75E | CTAs, icons, warm accents | Sunlight, optimism, actio |

### **Secondary Colors**

Support and balance our palette across maps, illustrations, or sub-branding.

| **Color Name** | **HEX** | **Use Case** | **Symbolism** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Cedar Brown | #8B5C3D | Text, texture, print-friendly contrast | Soil, stewardship, grounding |
| Sky Mist | #E1E7E6 | Backgrounds, negative space | Air, minimalism, spaciousness |
| Driftwood Gray | #B1B4A9 | Typography, icons | Stone, timelessness, neutrality |
| Heron Blue | #5A7181 | Alternate brand use, seasonal elements | Wildlife, calm, sophistication |

### **Highlight Colors**

Use sparingly — for emotional punch in campaigns or story elements.

| **Color Name** | **HEX** | **Use Case** | **Symbolism** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Wild Lupine | #A675B6 | Seasonal materials, print features | Biodiversity, bloom, spirit |
| Dune Coral | #EF7964 | Callouts, seasonal merch, web graphics | Warmth, human touch, activation |

## 🟢 **Door County Land Trust Logo & Rebrand Summary**

### Project: Visual Identity + Messaging Strategy Refresh

**Organization**: Door County Land Trust (DCLT)

**Purpose**: Establish a flexible, timeless, and mission-driven visual identity that connects to nature, community, and the conservation legacy of Door County.

---

## 🔷 CORE BRAND GOALS

- Reflect **local ecology, stewardship, and seasonal ephemerality**
- Appeal to **retiree donors, nature lovers, and regional community**
- Create a **tiered logo system**: full logo, simplified badge, and favicon/icon
- Integrate with **website redesign and communications overhaul**
- Stay accessible, print-friendly, merch-friendly, and scalable

---

## 🔶 CONCEPT DIRECTIONS  EXPLORED

Each was developed as a thematic style direction and/or visual prototype:

### 1. **Botanical Folklore Style**

*Inspired by Victorian field guides & Nordic folk art.*

✔ Features:

- Line-drawn plants like trillium, jack-in-the-pulpit, hepatica
- Turtles and other hidden fauna
- Soft natural palette: sage, clay, ivory, rust
- Embellished illustrations, serif type
    
    ✔ Use: journal covers, signage, seasonal merch
    

✅ **Finals Generated**:

- Full illustration with turtle and flowers
- Refined logo version with just trillium (w/o turtle)
- Stackable badge design with serif type
    
    📁 Filename example: `DCLT_logo_botanical_folk_style_trillium_jack_in_the_pulpit.png`
    

---

### 2. **Vintage Explorer Map Aesthetic**

*Inspired by WPA posters, topography, and compass iconography.*

✔ Features:

- Door County peninsula map with contour lines
- Compass rose, water ripple motifs
- Goldenrod, moss, driftwood tones
    
    
    ✘ Outcome: Did not feel as ownable; I chose to move on
    

---

### 3. **Feather & Fieldmark System**

*Minimal, glyph-based brand language*

✔ Features:

- Central feather logo
- Symbolic fieldmarks for ecosystems (dots, waves, rings)
- Black on cream style with modular symbols
    
    📁 Filename example: `DCLT_logo_feather_fieldmark_system_black_glyphs_minimalist.png`
    

---

### 4. **Soft Geometry + Handcrafted Texture**

*Based on block prints, Ghibli naturalism, retro composition*

✔ Features:

- Bold, color-blocked waves, leaves, and trees
- Rounded forms with hand-textured details
- Palette: chalky terracotta, spruce, denim, mustard
    
    📁 Filename example: `DCLT_logo_wpa_style_landscape_sunset_stripes_bird_tree_badge.png`
    

---

### 5. **Moodboard-Inspired Style (Final Stretch Direction)**

*I selected a group of logos/posters I loved (uploaded screenshot).*

✔ Key Traits:

- **Mid-century modern + WPA influence**
- Earthy color palette (teal, rust, mustard, pine)
- Simplified silhouettes of wildlife, water, trees
- Modular layout: icons + landscape blocks
- Font pairing: bold serif or geometric small caps

✅ **Developed From Moodboard**:

- Heron and tree scenes
- Sunset water waves and geometric trees
- Scalable visual system for preserves, programs, etc.
📁 Example title: `DCLT_logo_variation_moodboard_inspired_waves_heron_trees.png`

---

## 🟨 TIERED LOGO SYSTEM PLAN

We will be committed to building a logo suite including:

### 1. **Primary Logo**

- Full version (botanical or landscape) with “Door County Land Trust”
- Stylized color palette, scalable for signage and web

### 2. **Simplified/Secondary**

- One plant or animal icon
- Used for stamps, print collateral, field gear

### 3. **Favicon/Icon**

- Standalone glyph (turtle, feather, trillium, peninsula)
- Used for browser tab, buttons, patches

✅ Icons created:

- Feather, turtle, trillium, peninsula map, cliff/tree badge

---

# 1. Redesign Concept Evaluation – Shield & Trillium

# Overview

This evaluation uses the **Logo & Visual Identity Rubric** to assess the existing Door County Land Trust logo. Purpose is to document how the current mark aligns (or fails to align) with conservation values, focus group feedback, and long-term identity needs.

---

## Scoring Rubric

| **Category** | **Definition** | **Weight** | **Score (1–5)** | **Weighted Score** | **Notes** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Mission Alignment** | Reflects conservation values, trust, permanence, and focus group insights | 25% | 3 | 0.75 | Represents land + water + trillium, but feels “sanitized” and too formal. |
| **Authenticity** | Feels true to Door County’s landscape, community, and history | 15% | 3 | 0.45 | General Door County feel, but not specific/bluff details missing; generic tree + flower. |
| **Distinctiveness** | Stands out from other land trusts and local orgs | 15% | 2 | 0.30 | Similar shield style is common; easily confused with other nonprofits. |
| **Adaptability** | Works across signage, print, web, social, and merch | 15% | 4 | 0.60 | Functional at small sizes; simple shapes scale decently. |
| **Emotional Resonance** | Evokes pride, trust, and care for the land | 10% | 2 | 0.20 | Described by participants as “outdated” and “cold.” Limited emotional pull. |
| **Readability/Clarity** | Legible at all sizes, symbol clear without text | 10% | 4 | 0.40 | Good clarity and legibility, though somewhat flat. |
| **Longevity** | Likely to remain relevant 10–20 years | 10% | 2 | 0.20 | Feels dated today; unlikely to age well another decade. |

**Total Weighted Score:** **2.9 / 5.0 (58%)**

---

## Key Insights

- **Strengths:** Clear, simple, recognizable form; scales well; does depict bluff + water + trillium.
- **Weaknesses:** Perceived as outdated, sterile, too formal. Fails to spark emotional connection.
- **Focus Group Alignment:** Echoes feedback that the logo “feels sanitized,” lacks warmth, and doesn’t strongly convey authenticity or local specificity.

---

## Recommendation

- **Keep?** ❌ No (not aligned with focus group insights, dated)
- **Evolve?** ✅ Yes (elements like bluffs/water/trillium remain important, but need refreshed execution)
- **Drop?** ❌ Not entirely — symbolic building blocks should inform the new system.

---

## Next Steps

- Use this evaluation as a **baseline** against which new concepts are scored.
- Ensure new designs improve in **authenticity, distinctiveness, and emotional resonance** while retaining adaptability and clarity.

# Key Insights → Future Brand Strategy Steps

*Connecting research findings to concrete brand evolution actions.*

---

### **🎯 Purpose**

Document and align the most important audience, brand, and engagement insights that emerged from the 2024–2025 rebrand research — and map them directly to future decisions, deliverables, and checkpoints in the brand refresh process.

---

### **🔍 Key Insights**

### **1. Both legacy and new audiences care deeply about land protection**

> Despite generational and stylistic differences, everyone agrees land protection is the Land Trust’s core role.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Keep protection as the central brand pillar. Anchor messaging in protection-first language across homepage, campaigns, and appeals.

---

### **2. Younger audiences crave transparency, video, and interaction**

> Group 1 wants process visibility, user-generated content, and storytelling that makes them feel like participants.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Develop storytelling video plan and supporter overlay system (linked: [📖 Storytelling CRM Overlay System]). Introduce explainer content and participatory formats in campaigns.

---

### **3. Older supporters feel emotionally distanced from the newer brand tone**

> Long-term volunteers and donors miss the warmth and personal connection they once felt.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Design Legacy Circle touchpoints and nostalgic print materials. Integrate soft touches in brand tone and direct mail. (Linked: [Legacy Conservationist Engagement Plan])

---

### **4. Both groups prefer clean, authentic, local imagery — not stock or abstract design**

> Mood board feedback shows a strong aversion to dark/heavy visuals and non-Door-County scenes.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Prioritize real photography, local illustration, and maps. Kill all mountain/stock clichés. (Linked: [🖼️ Visual Identity Guidelines])

---

### **5. Event timing and volunteer opportunities are a barrier for working professionals**

> Mid-day weekday events limit inclusion for younger/working supporters.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Restructure volunteer program with evening/weekend slots and larger quarterly events. Use new brand system to visually highlight opportunities. (Linked: [Volunteer Strategy Refresh])

---

### **6. Print still matters — especially to legacy donors**

> Strong enthusiasm for calendars, newsletters, and direct mail among older supporters.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Ensure print-ready brand templates exist in the new system. Design for dual-channel flexibility (print + digital). (Linked: [Design Template Library])

---

### **7. The current logo is seen as outdated and confusing by both groups**

> “Too sanitized,” “boring,” and “teepee trees” all surfaced.
> 

**→ Strategy Step:**

Advance logo refinement that keeps the arch/window metaphor but adds clearer Door County references. User-test options across demographics. (Linked: [Finalize Logo & System])

---

### **✅ Success Criteria for This Page**

- Clearly connect insight → next action
- Link to relevant strategy or task pages
- Update once per quarter with completed steps
- Share in internal brand strategy reviews

# Designer Collaboration & Pre-Design Kickoff

This document outlines how designers will collaborate on brand identity explorations for Door County Land Trust. It ensures clarity, fairness, and alignment with organizational values.

---

## 1. Purpose

- Avoid “winner-take-all bakeoff” dynamics.
- Frame all concepts as *parallel explorations* of shared values, not competing designer outputs.
- Ensure both designers feel included, respected, and supported.
- Build a foundation for collaborative refinement once initial concepts are developed.

---

## 2. Pre-Design Kickoff

### **a. Shared Brainstorm (1–2 hrs)**

- Review the **Values & Keywords (Quick Reference Checklist)**.
- Map possible directions (e.g., bluff realism, stylized heritage marks, water emphasis, flora/fauna inclusion).
- Identify *must-haves* (bluff, water, no gradients) vs. *flexible elements* (tree species, fauna, typography).

### **b. Divvy Up Idea Spaces (examples)**

- Designer A: Explore **realistic/landform fidelity** directions.
- Designer B: Explore **stylized/heritage mark** directions.*(Adjust division based on interests and strengths.)*

### **c. Alignment Check**

- Confirm what each designer will explore (2 directions each).
- Agree on level of fidelity (logo sketches + minimal applications, not full brand systems yet).
- Set a checkpoint date for first share-back.

---

## 3. Concept Depth (Round 1)

Each designer develops **two independent concepts**:

- Logo mark (with text treatment where relevant).
- Simple applications (signage mockup, digital thumbnail, print test).
- Optional: small supporting element (icon/ornamental/illustrative) if it reinforces the direction.

Deliverables are exploratory, not polished final art.

---

## 4. Collaboration Guidelines

- **Independence in Execution**: Each designer creates their own files and owns their 2 directions.
- **Mutual Support**: Designers share progress and seek feedback based on strengths (e.g., typography, illustration, mockups).
- **Neutral Presentation**: When shared with stakeholders, concepts are framed as *team explorations*.
- **Evaluation Neutrality**: Scoring rubric is applied equally across all directions, regardless of author.
- **Refinement Round**: Once one or two directions rise to the top, *both designers* contribute to evolving the chosen design(s).

---

## 5. Evaluation & Next Steps

1. Conduct scoring rubric session with the stakeholder group.
2. Identify high-scoring directions and gaps.
3. Both designers collaborate on refinement of selected direction(s).
4. Document process and decisions for continuity and transparency.

---

## 6. Timeline

| **Milestone** | **Date** | **Notes** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Kickoff Brainstorm | Aug 20 | Align on idea spaces & boundaries |
| Concept Round 1 Share-back | Sept 3 | Each designer presents 2 directions |
| Internal Evaluation | Sept 10 | Use rubric + group synthesis |
| Development Committee Presentation | Sept 16 | Update sub-commitee on designs |
| Refinement Round | Sept 17–24 | Both designers collaborate on selected direction(s) |
| Stakeholder Evaluation  | Oct 1 |  |
| Refinement Round | Oct 1-17 |  |
| Final Presentation | Oct 17 | Refined brand direction ready for board input |
| Board Meeting Presentation | Nov 4 |  |

---

✅ **Use this document as the guiding framework** to ensure clarity, fairness, and structured collaboration throughout the design process.

# Brand Identity Design Kickoff Plan

# Purpose

Create a clear, collaborative, and mission-aligned process for developing and evaluating brand identity concepts—ensuring inclusion, transparency, and strong creative output from both designers.

---

## References

- [[Focus Group–Derived Moodboard Evaluation Framework|**Focus Group–Derived Values & Keywords**]] [](../%E2%80%94%20Logo%20&%20Visual%20Identity%20Evaluation%20Roadmap%2024e2a8cd5755809aadb2e107a5e9e938.md)(already developed): Use these as "truth anchors" for concept creation and scoring.
- [[— Logo & Visual Identity Evaluation Roadmap|**Design Evaluation Rubric**]] (already developed): Apply during review to reduce subjectivity and ensure buy-in.

---

## Process Summary

### 1. Shared Foundation

- Review **Values & Keywords** together.
- Agree on fixed elements vs. open creative space.
- Align on what success looks like before designing.

### 2. Concept Ownership

- **Round 1**: Each designer produces **two distinct concepts**.
- Concepts can share core elements but should differ in creative approach, tone, and/or symbol set.

### 3. Concept Depth (Round 1)

For each concept, include:

- Primary logo mark
- Suggested wordmark treatment
- 2–3 mockups in key contexts (signage, social media, merchandise)
- 2–3 sentence description of concept intent
- **Optional brand expression elements**: One or two supporting pieces (e.g., simple icon, ornamental linework, illustrative style sample, or website hero mockup) that reinforce the concept’s tone and adaptability.
- *Note*: Skip full color system or final typography at this stage.

### 4. Review Cadence

- Present all Round 1 concepts together.
- Use the [[— Logo & Visual Identity Evaluation Roadmap|**rubric**]] for scoring.
- Discuss and shortlist 1–2 concepts for refinement.

### 5. Refinement Phase

For shortlisted concepts:

- Finalize typography
- Develop full color palette
- Test applications across digital, print, and physical signage
- Update mockups to final fidelity

### 6. Inclusion & Voice

- Each designer presents their own work.
- Credit contributions clearly in updates. but end product is a “we” accomplishment
- Allow each designer to propose one exploration area or “wild card” idea.

---

## Deliverables by Phase

**Round 1: Concept Exploration**

- 2 concepts per designer
- Each concept: logo mark, wordmark, 2–3 mockups, short intent description

**Round 2: Refinement**

- Chosen concept(s) refined with final typography, palette, applications

---

## Timeline (Adjust as Needed)

**Week 1**

- Kickoff meeting: review values, keywords, rubric, success criteria
- Decide concept ownership approach and guardrails

**Week 2–3**

- Independent concept development (2 each)
- Midpoint check-in (optional)

**Week 4**

- Concept presentation & scoring
- Shortlist concepts for refinement

**Week 5–6**

- Refinement of shortlisted concepts
- Update mockups with finalized brand elements

**Week 7**

- Final presentation & scoring
- Select final concept

---

## Review Dates (Proposed)

- **Kickoff**: August 18,2025
- **Round 1 Presentation**: September 1, 2025
- **Refinement Review**: September 15, 2025
- **Final Decision**: September 25, 2025

---

## Implementation                       Notes

- Use the **rubric** for *all* review stages.
- Archive scores and notes in Notion for decision history.
- Ensure all mockups use realistic contexts to simulate real-world impact.

# Why Rebrand? Strategy & Rationale

## Goals of the Rebrand

- Improve fundraising capacity
- Explain our work more clearly
- Align messaging and visuals with mission and beliefs
- Equip staff and board with tools to communicate effectively
- Strengthen external support and confidence
- Enhance understanding of our mission and impact
- Reach and engage the right audiences
- Ensure consistency across fundraising, outreach, and advocacy materials
- Differentiate the organization in a crowded space
- Increase supporters, activists, and program participants
- Streamline how staff and board represent the organization
- Communicate clearly and professionally with donors and stakeholders

## Strategic Questions:

- What will be the impact of this change?
- Will donor retention be affected?
- What top three things do we want to be known for?
- What do our donors have in common?
- Who do we benefit the most?
- What is our strongest differentiator?
- What will be the lasting benefits of this brand refresh?

## Considerations

- Staff must be committed to the process
- Leadership buy-in is essential

## Rationale

> A brand refresh for a land trust should communicate not only the ecological importance of Door County’s landscapes, but also the tangible benefits to residents and visitors—cleaner air and water, flood protection, natural beauty, and a lasting legacy. Tying conservation to quality of life helps our message resonate with a broader audience.
> 

## Why Now?

### Does Our Land Trust Need a Rebrand?

Our mission and the conservation landscape have evolved. A rebrand ensures our identity reflects who we are now—and where we’re going.

We’ve moved beyond land acquisition into climate resilience, restoration, and community-driven conservation. But does our current brand clearly communicate that?

Donor behavior has also changed. While longtime members remain core, younger generations engage differently—expecting storytelling, digital tools, and measurable outcomes. If our brand doesn’t meet them where they are, we risk losing relevance and support.

## Key Questions We’re Asking Ourselves

- Does our brand reflect our full mission?
- Are we effectively engaging new generations?
- Is our identity outdated or confusing?
- Is our messaging modern and compelling?
- Are we perceived as leaders in policy and action?

## Where We See Opportunity

A rebrand won’t change who we are—but it will help us **tell our story more clearly, powerfully, and urgently**. It can:

- Make our identity clearer to donors, landowners, and partners
- Differentiate us from other environmental nonprofits
- Strengthen our digital presence
- Attract new audiences while honoring long-time members
- Support stronger fundraising and advocacy

## What’s Next?

Before any major changes, we’ll seek feedback from our community—members, donors, volunteers, and partners. We want to understand:

- What resonates about our current brand
- Where clarity or modernization is needed
- How to connect more deeply with those who support our mission

> This is an exciting opportunity to position DCLT for the future of conservation—while staying true to the values that guide us.
> 

## Why Rebranding Matters for Land Trusts

Rebranding helps land trusts stay relevant in a fast-changing world. Environmental challenges, community priorities, and donor expectations are evolving—our brand must evolve too.

A brand is more than a logo. It’s a signal of who we are and what we stand for. When branding lags behind, it creates confusion, limits engagement, and undercuts impact.

### Top Reasons Land Trusts Rebrand:

1. **Expanding Mission**
    
    From acquisition to climate resilience, if branding doesn’t evolve, the full scope is missed.
    
2. **New Donor Expectations**
    
    Donors now expect transparency, measurable impact, and digital engagement. Your brand must reflect that.
    
3. **Crowded Nonprofit Landscape**
    
    Clear, differentiated branding helps stand out and attract support.
    
4. **Stronger Advocacy & Public Voice**
    
    A modern brand supports credibility in policy, community leadership, and storytelling.
    
5. **Engaging Future Generations**
    
    Younger supporters want brands that feel relevant, bold, and values-driven.
    

---

> A rebrand isn’t just a new look—it’s the launch of a new chapter. It’s a chance to signal that we’re ready for the future of conservation.
> 

## Why Now?

### Does Our Land Trust Need a Rebrand?

Our mission and the conservation landscape have evolved. A rebrand ensures our identity reflects who we are now—and where we’re going.

We’ve moved beyond land acquisition into climate resilience, restoration, and community-driven conservation. But does our current brand clearly communicate that?

Donor behavior has also changed. While longtime members remain core, younger generations engage differently—expecting storytelling, digital tools, and measurable outcomes. If our brand doesn’t meet them where they are, we risk losing relevance and support.

# —— Confirmation Email Details

Thank you for joining us for this important conversation. Below is a brief outline of what to expect during our upcoming session:

**1. Welcome & Introductions**

Meet our team, review community agreements, and share what you love about Door County.

**2. Your Connection to DCLT**

How you first heard about the Land Trust, why you got involved, and what you value most.

**3. DCLT’s Role in the Community**

Discussion about the challenges facing Door County and the role you think the Land Trust should play.

**4. Visual Moodboard Reactions**

Review 3 possible design directions and share what feels most (or least) like “DCLT” to you.

**5. Communication Preferences**

How you prefer to hear from us, what messaging resonates, and what doesn’t.

**6. Wrap-Up**

Final thoughts, what we’ve learned from you, and how your input will shape our work.

**What you’ll need:**

- A quiet space
- A computer or tablet with Zoom access
- Optional: Pen and paper for notes during moodboard review

**Questions?**

Contact Don Krumpos at [dkrumpos@doorcountylandtrust.org](mailto:dkrumpos@doorcountylandtrust.org)

# —— Symbolism System

This document outlines the symbolic meaning behind each core visual element used in the Door County Land Trust brand system. These elements were chosen not only for their aesthetic quality but also for their alignment with the organization’s mission, values, and brand archetypes: Caregiver, Explorer, and (in moments of activation) Hero.

---

### 🌿 The Trillium (Core Glyph)

**Symbolizes:**

- **Protection**: Of Door County’s lands and waters
- **Care**: For people, place, and partnerships
- **Future**: Intergenerational stewardship and legacy

**Petal Meanings:**

1. Protection (mission)
2. Care (values)
3. Future (vision)

**Uses:**

- Primary glyph
- Favicon
- Donor pins or volunteer badges
- Pattern motif (repeating radial symmetry)

---

### 🌳 Evergreen Trees

**Symbolizes:**

- Permanence and rootedness
- Shelter and belonging
- Regional identity

**Uses:**

- Scenic logo backdrop
- Brand illustrations and poster art
- Sub-brand expansion (e.g., preserve-specific logos)

---

### 🌊 The River (or Water Path)

**Symbolizes:**

- The flow of time and legacy
- Water quality and watershed protection
- Connection across landscapes and communities

**Uses:**

- Connective element in logos and illustrations
- Potential abstract form for pattern or icon system
- Part of dynamic or animated versions

---

### ☀️ The Sun (Circle Motif)

**Symbolizes:**

- Continuity, cycles, and renewal
- Hope, resilience, and energy
- Data and science (as a circular system/feedback loop)

**Uses:**

- Inverse or reversed mark
- Stamp or field-tested mark
- Scientific reports or climate communications

---

### 📍 The Bluff / Peninsula Shape

**Symbolizes:**

- A specific sense of place (Door County geography)
- Protection of landform, shoreline, and horizon
- Explorer archetype: perspective and discovery

**Uses:**

- Subtle brand pattern
- Seasonal postcards or map headers
- Visitor materials (field guides, signage)

---

### 📈 Compass Rose / Navigation Motifs

**Symbolizes:**

- Purposeful direction
- Explorer and Hero archetypes
- Youth and new member appeal

**Uses:**

- Youth programming
- Exploratory tools or campaign graphics
- Interpretation signage

---

### 🌻 Supporting Botanical Elements (ferns, wildflowers, grasses)

**Symbolizes:**

- Biodiversity
- Native plant communities
- Interconnectedness of systems

**Uses:**

- Border embellishment
- Digital illustration kit
- Print collateral and packaging

---

### 🌈 Color Symbolism

- **Forest Green**: Protection, stability, groundedness
- **Ochre Gold**: Legacy, sunlight, ecological value
- **Cream/Off-white**: Simplicity, honesty, approachability
- **Earth Brown (optional)**: Soil, rootedness, balance
- **Slate Blue (optional accent)**: Water, science, calm observation

---

### 📅 Application Timeline (2025–2026)

- Finalize system in brand book
- Field test glyphs in campaigns
- Roll out badge and favicon variants
- Expand into patterns and merch by Spring 2026

### **🌲🌲 Symbolism of Two Trees**

### **Past + Future**

- One tree honors the **legacy of conservation**—those who came before.
- The other stands for **future generations**—those you’re protecting it for.
- Symbolic read: **Stewardship across time.**

---

# Website Overhaul Roadmap (2025–2026)

# 🧭 Website Overhaul Roadmap (2025–2026)

A high-level summary of the phases, milestones, and current status for the full DCLT website overhaul—including strategy, content, design, technical build, and launch. This roadmap complements deeper pages (Preserve Explorer, Modular Blocks, IA) and provides alignment for internal stakeholders.

---

## ✅ Phase 1: Strategy & Discovery (Q1–Q2 2025)

🔍 This phase focused on gathering internal input, aligning goals, and developing a content and architecture strategy grounded in real user and staff needs.

- ✅ Staff interviews across departments
- ✅ Cross-synthesis summary complete
- ✅ Website audit (legacy site + priority fixes)
- ✅ Homepage concept mockups explored
- ✅ Sitemap and IA draft created
- ✅ Supporter personas + psychographic funnels (internal planning)
- ✅ Alignment with Rebrand goals and content ops

---

## 🧱 Phase 2: IA & Content Modeling (Q2–Q3 2025)

📦 Defining reusable content structures, templates, and calls to action for each major audience journey.

<details><summary>🧱 Modular Content Architecture</summary>

- ✅ Content types mapped (Preserve, Story, CTA, Get Involved, etc.)
- ✅ Modular content blocks documented
- ✅ Field definitions scoped (ACF, GraphQL)
- 🔄 Templates for each core page in progress
- 🔄 Strategy brief for content migration underway
- 🔄 Funnel and CTA mapping by persona segment in development

</details>

<details><summary>🧭 Page-Level Information Architecture</summary>

- ✅ Preserve, Donate, Get Involved: wireframe layouts and block plans
- ✅ Landowner “Protect Your Land” Hub structured
- ✅ Peer IA scans referenced
- 🔄 Homepage IA refinement underway

</details>

---

## 🎨 Phase 3: Design & Wireframes (Q3–Q4 2025)

🖼 Merging rebrand with a clean, modular UI system that supports flexible storytelling, donor conversion, and preserve engagement.

<details><summary>🖼 Wireframe Development</summary>

- ✅ Core wireframes (Home, Preserve, Donate, Volunteer, Contact)
- 🔄 Wireframes integrated with real copy (ongoing)
- 🔄 Feedback loop with staff and stakeholders

</details>

<details><summary>🗺 Interactive Components</summary>

- ✅ Preserve Explorer: map-based UI prototype built
- 🔄 Leaflet/React integration in test phase
- 🔄 Event & stewardship overlays in development
- 🔄 Live filtering and analytics hooks planned

</details>

<details><summary>🎨 Visual System Alignment</summary>

- ✅ Rebrand elements (type, color, icons) integrated
- 🔄 Testing accessible color and layout patterns
- 🔄 Hero components and illustration system in design

</details>

---

## ⚙️ Phase 4: Technical Build (Q4 2025 – Q1 2026)

🧰 Developing a scalable, performance-minded site architecture using WordPress (PHP + ACF) with embedded React modules and future-friendly design.

<details><summary>🧰 Dev Environment & Architecture</summary>

- ✅ Local WP theme with Tailwind and ACF initialized
- ✅ Post types and custom fields (Preserve, Story, Event) structured
- 🔄 React + Leaflet map components loaded via shortcode
- 🔄 CMS training and fallback theme in progress

</details>

<details><summary>📊 Analytics & Accessibility</summary>

- 🔄 Lighthouse/a11y testing plan in place
- 🔄 GA4 and form tracking integration planning
- 🔄 SEO schema blocks (Preserves, Stories, Events) scoped

</details>

---

## 🚀 Phase 5: Launch Prep (Q1 2026)

🎯 Preparing for a clean, phased go-live with staff onboarding, QA, and soft internal rollout.

<details><summary>📦 Content Migration</summary>

- 🔄 Migration planning spreadsheet in progress
- 🔄 Priority pages identified
- 🔄 Rewriting and reviewing existing content

</details>

<details><summary>🧪 QA + Feedback</summary>

- 🔄 Cross-browser/device testing planned
- 🔄 Internal team preview and feedback loop
- 🔄 Accessibility and navigation stress testing

</details>

<details><summary>📣 Go-Live & Communications</summary>

- 🔄 Internal launch (Board & staff)
- 🔄 Public announcement timeline coordinated with rebrand
- 🔄 Post-launch monitoring and iteration

</details>

---

# — Strategic Initiatives – Web Integration Build Spec

(Public Hub + Site-wide Embeds)

## PURPOSE
Transform the “Strategic Initiatives in Plain Language” content into a living, interactive web layer that:

- Lives on its own /strategy hub page.
- Appears in context-appropriate spots across the site.
- Uses non-linear web navigation to connect initiatives with stories, preserves, events, volunteer roles, and giving opportunities.
- Stays accurate over time with clear ownership and review cycles.
- Presents the strategic plan                                ([[Website Strategy Hub]]) in a **public-facing, plain-language, fun, and friendly format**.

---

1. VISUAL & STORYTELLING APPROACH
- The hub and embeds should function as an **interactive infographic** rather than a static list.
- Each initiative should be represented visually (iconography, photography, illustration, or short video loops).
- Incorporate **scroll-based storytelling (“scrollytelling”)** to reveal goals, metrics, and stories as the user moves through the page.
- Use **progress visuals** (animated counters, progress bars, milestone markers) to display metrics instead of static numbers.
- Pair every metric or goal with a short human-centered story or example.
- Ensure visuals are **accessible**:
    - Provide text equivalents for all key visuals.
    - Keep animations optional or subtle; provide pause controls if necessary.
    - Maintain full keyboard and screen reader compatibility.
- Tone should remain **inviting and clear**, with active verbs and direct, relatable language.
- Design should make it easy for users to jump directly to the initiatives that interest them (non-linear exploration).

---

## CONTENT MODEL

Taxonomy: initiative (9 terms)

- Land Protection
- Stewardship
- Working Lands
- Conservation Partnerships
- Community Engagement
- Access, Inclusion, and Cultural Competence
- Volunteers
- Organizational Capacity
- Fundraising

Custom fields per initiative term:

- goal (long text)
- messages (multi-line text or array)
- metrics_labels (array)
- icon (string: SVG or lucide icon name)
- color_token (string: Tailwind token)
- slug_override (string, optional)

Attach taxonomy to: post (stories/news), preserve (CPT), event (CPT), volunteer_role (CPT), optionally page.

---

## PAGE IA

/strategy (Hub page):

- Hero: “Strategic Initiatives in Plain Language”
- Accordion grid: 9 initiatives (Goal, Messaging, Metrics) – expandable.
- Related work strip: auto-pulls content tagged to each initiative.
- CTA band: “Back this work” (Donate, Volunteer, Join).

/strategy/{initiative-slug} (Optional detail pages):

- Full initiative narrative.
- Related stories/events/volunteer roles filtered by taxonomy.
- How you can help (initiative-specific CTAs).

---

## REUSABLE BLOCKS

InitiativeBadge: tiny pill (icon + name) linking to initiative page.

InitiativeEmbed: Goal + Messaging + compact Metrics.

InitiativeGrid: Grid of selected initiatives.

InitiativeRelated: Auto-query related content by initiative.

KPIList: Metrics list for initiative.

---

## CROSS-SITE EMBEDDING STRATEGY

Homepage: “Our Work” grid → 9 initiatives; related stories carousel.

Preserve pages: InitiativeBadges showing linked initiatives (“This preserve advances: Stewardship, Land Protection”).

Volunteer hub: Filter volunteer roles by initiative; embed Volunteer initiative messaging.

Events: InitiativeBadges on event cards; filter events by initiative.

Donate/Join pages: Dynamic copy block: “Your gift powers {initiative},” rotating.

News/Stories: Initiative chips under headlines; click-through to initiative pages.

Footer: Mini-strategy strip linking to /strategy.

---

## GOVERNANCE

Initiative content – Owner: Communications – Update every 6 months – Trigger: Strategic plan updates.

Taxonomy tags on content – Owner: All content editors – Update ongoing – Trigger: New story/event/preserve.

Review metrics – Owner: Development/Analytics – Update every 6 months – Trigger: Annual report cycle.

---

## MEASUREMENT PLAN

Track clicks on InitiativeBadges and InitiativeEmbeds (GA4 custom events).

Build /strategy-dashboard to show:

- Number of tagged content per initiative.
- Traffic to initiative pages.
- CTA conversions from initiative blocks.

---

## IMPLEMENTATION CHECKLIST

Development:

- Create initiative taxonomy in code.
- Add custom fields to taxonomy terms.
- Attach taxonomy to relevant CPTs.
- Build reusable Gutenberg blocks for Badge, Embed, Grid, Related, KPIList.
- Style according to brand system.
- Ensure accessibility for accordions and dynamic blocks.

Design:

- Wireframe /strategy hub (desktop + mobile) with infographic/scrollytelling elements.
- Define color/icon for each initiative.
- Create compact + full-width embed styles.

Content:

- Load initiative content into taxonomy fields.
- Tag existing stories/events/preserves with initiatives.
- Draft “How you can help” CTAs per initiative.

---

## VISUAL REFERENCE / WIREFRAME NOTES

![image.png](%E2%80%94%20Strategic%20Initiatives%20%E2%80%93%20Web%20Integration%20Build%20Sp%2024c2a8cd575580079f18cf2e2d444086/image.png)

---

## USER FLOW EXAMPLE

1. Visitor lands on Preserve detail page for a new acquisition.
2. Sees InitiativeBadges for “Land Protection” and “Community Engagement.”
3. Clicks “Land Protection” → /strategy/land-protection.
4. Reads Goal/Messaging → sees recent stories & “Donate to Protect Land” CTA.
5. Donates or signs up for volunteer role.

---

## ACCESSIBILITY & TONE

- All accordions must be keyboard navigable and use ARIA attributes.
- Icons are decorative unless essential to meaning.
- Keep messaging plain and direct.
- Avoid euphemisms; use clear verbs like protect, restore, partner, engage.

---

[[Strategic Initiatives in Plain Language|to see the Public Facing language see this document.]]

![image.png](%E2%80%94%20Strategic%20Initiatives%20%E2%80%93%20Web%20Integration%20Build%20Sp%2024c2a8cd575580079f18cf2e2d444086/image%201.png)

# 🧠 UX + Interaction Design Decisions Log

## Click vs Hover - Subnav Interaction Decision

### **🧠 Decision**

Use **click to reveal** for desktop sub-navigation menus (instead of hover-to-reveal behavior).

---

### **💬 Rationale**

- **Predictability:** Users can control the interaction more precisely; avoids accidental activation from passing cursor movement.
- **Consistency:** Mobile and tablet already require click/tap. Using click on desktop unifies behavior across devices.
- **Accessibility:** Hover states don’t exist on touchscreens and can introduce cognitive load for users with motor or visual impairments.
- **User Control:** Click to reveal respects intentional interaction. Avoids “menu surprise” when users are navigating quickly.
- **Evidence from user frustration:** Team members (incl. Comms) report personal annoyance with hover menus when quickly moving the cursor — common and valid UX complaint.

---

### **🦾 Accessibility Notes**

- Click-based menus are:
    - Easier to make **keyboard-accessible**
    - More **screen reader-compatible**
    - Less likely to interfere with **focus order or skip navigation**
- Hover-only menus fail **WCAG 2.1 Guideline 1.4.13 (Content on Hover or Focus)** if not implemented carefully.

---

### **🔁 Reversal Criteria**

We are open to reverting to hover behavior **only if:**

- Analytics or user testing show confusion or drop-off
- Stakeholders present a compelling case with accessibility-safe implementation                  
- A hybrid interaction model (click-to-open with hover cues) becomes justified and testable

---

### **📚 References & Inspiration**

- [Nielsen Norman Group – Hover Menus](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/mega-menus-work-well/)
- [WCAG 2.1 Guidelines – Content on Hover or Focus](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/content-on-hover-or-focus.html)
- [Inclusive Components – Menus](https://inclusive-components.design/menus-menu-buttons/)

## **List View vs. Map View**

**Date:** July 22, 2025

**Owner:** LandComm

**Status:** Resolved

---

### **🎯 Problem**

Users in List View and Map View may have different goals. We need to decide:

- Whether List View should behave like Map View
- If filters should persist
- How to support both spatial and detail-oriented browsing

---

### **🧭 Insight**

**Map View users** are in a *“where is it?”* mindset

→ Spatial relevance, trip planning, location-first thinking

**List View users** are in a *“what is it?”* mindset

→ Content detail, attribute filtering, side-by-side comparison

These modes reflect different user **intent** and **cognitive framing**.

---

### **✅ Decisions**

| **Area** | **Decision** |
| --- | --- |
| Filters | Filters will persist in List View |
| Detail View | Clicking a List Item will open the same overlay panel as Map View (not a separate page) |
| Spatial Awareness | Each card will include a **“View on Map”** button or location label |
| Canonical URLs | Preserve detail pages will still exist for SEO, but users primarily explore through the panel overlay |

---

### **🔄 Implications**

- This avoids fragmenting UX into two disjointed systems
- Maintains app-like continuity across all modes
- Supports both exploratory and decision-focused user journeys
- Sets a pattern that can be reused in other DCLT interfaces

---

### **🔗 Related**

- [UX System: Design Paradigms Log](https://www.notion.so/notion-link-if-you-have-it)
- [Preserve Explorer – Wireframes](https://www.notion.so/link)
- [Preserve Explorer – IA Map](https://www.notion.so/link)

## Breadcrumb Retention Rationale

We’re retaining a persistent breadcrumb component on all pages (including Preserve Detail) for the following reasons:

- **Spatial consistency**: Keeping the breadcrumb in the same location across views builds user trust and predictability.
- **Cognitive orientation**: Even on pages with a clear visual title (e.g. “Bear Creek”), the breadcrumb reinforces site structure and provides a fast return path to "All Preserves."
- **Avoids visual jumpiness**: Removing it from some pages would cause the main content area to shift vertically, which creates dissonance and breaks flow.
- **Low visual weight, high utility**: The design is minimal and subordinate to the header, so it doesn’t compete for attention but remains useful.

📍Design is touch-friendly, viewport-aligned, and consistent with the site’s overall grid and hierarchy.

### Heuristic: Visibility of System Status

Breadcrumbs contribute to the user's understanding of “where they are” within the system at all times—especially useful in map-based navigation, where entry points may vary. This reinforces the user's mental model of site structure and provides reassurance through persistent orientation cues.
